question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
Solve the differential equation:

\begin{align*}y'-2y=4+e^{3t}\end{align*} (\emph{Give the general solution})
hints:
Try using an integrating factor of $e^{-2t}$ (so multiply both sides of
the equation by this factor). This $-2$ in the exponent of \emph{e}
comes from the coefficient of the \emph{y} term in the differential
equation.
